bestBHT.bht: The high priests had to offer sacrifices daily, but Jesus, as the eternal High Priest, did not need to do so since His sacrifice was sufficient to atone for all sins forever. The repetition of sacrifices by the high priests highlights the superiority of Jesus's sacrifice, which was offered once for all. He offered Himself without sin and put an end to the need for further sacrifices. Through His complete and acceptable sacrifice, Jesus obtained complete salvation for all believers.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The 'daily' strictly belongs to Christ, not to the high priests, 'who needeth not daily, as those high priests (year by year, and their subordinate priests daily), to offer.'
The high priest's double offering on the day of atonement, the bullock for himself, and the goat for the people's sins, had its counterpart in the TWO lambs offered daily by the ordinary priests.
The sufficiency of the one sacrifice to atone for all sins for ever, resulted from its absolute spotlessness.
Albert Barnes: He was so holy that he needed no sacrifice for himself, and all that he did was in behalf of others.
The offering which he made, though presented but once, was so ample and perfect that it had sufficient merit for all the sins of the world, and needed never to be repeated.
Thus, he put an end to sacrifice, for when he made the great atonement it was complete, and there was no need that any more blood should be shed for human guilt.
Marvin Vincent: Who needeth not daily (kaq' hJmeran). Apparently inconsistent with ch. 9 7, but the sense is, 'who hath no need day by day as the high priest had (year by year) to offer sacrifices,' etc."
The great point is repetition, whether daily or yearly."
Once [εφαπαξ] . Rend. once for all. Contrasted with daily.
John Calvin: One of the defects of the ancient priesthood was, that the high priest offered sacrifices for his own sins; how then could he have pacified God for others, who had God justly displeased with himself?
Then they were by no means equal to the work of expiating for sins.

The case with Christ was wholly different; for he himself needed no sacrifice, as he was sprinkled with no spot of sin; and such was the sacrifice, that it was alone sufficient to the end of the world, for he offered himself.
Archibald T. Robertson: προτερον. Regular adverb for comparison between two, though πρωτον often occurs also (John 1:41), with επειτα (then) following.
For the sins (τον). Only the article in the Greek with repetition of υπερ or of αμαρτιων.
When he offered up himself (εαυτον ανενεγκας). First aorist active participle of αναφερω, to offer up.
John Gill: He (the high priest, they say) offers sacrifices for the sins of the people, for his own בקדמיתא, 'first,' ולבתר, 'and afterwards for the sins of the people.'"
Christ needed not to offer for his own, nor could he, for he had none of his own; what he had was by imputation.

Christ offered himself, his whole human nature, soul and body, and both as in union with his divine nature; and this being offered to God freely and voluntarily, in the room and stead of his people, was acceptable to God: hereby justice was satisfied; the law fulfilled; sin taken away, and complete salvation obtained.
John Wesley: He offered once for all: not for his own sins, for he then offered up himself "without spot to God."

bhtAttempts.bht: The book of Hebrews emphasizes that Jesus, as the eternal High Priest, surpasses the earthly high priests who needed to offer sacrifices daily. Unlike them, Jesus's sacrifice was sufficient to atone for all sins forever because of its absolute spotlessness. Jesus's sacrifice was once for all, rendering any repetition unnecessary. He offered himself, without any sin, and his sacrifice was complete and acceptable to God. Thus, he put an end to the need for further sacrifices and secured complete salvation for all who believe in him.

The earthly high priests were required to offer sacrifices daily, but Jesus, as the eternal High Priest, had no need to do so. His sacrifice, offered once for all, was spotless and sufficient to atone for all sins forever. By offering himself without sin, Jesus put an end to the need for further sacrifices. His sacrifice was complete and acceptable to God, securing complete salvation for all who believe in him.

The book of Hebrews emphasizes that Jesus, as the eternal High Priest, surpasses the high priests who needed to offer sacrifices daily. Jesus's sacrifice was sufficient to atone for all sins forever because of its absolute spotlessness. The repetition of the high priests' sacrifices, whether daily or yearly, highlights the superiority of Jesus's once-for-all sacrifice. He offered himself, without any sin, and his sacrifice was complete and acceptable to God. Thus, he put an end to the need for further sacrifices and secured complete salvation for all who believe in him.

The earthly high priests needed to offer sacrifices daily, while Jesus, as the eternal High Priest, had no need for such repeated offerings. His spotless sacrifice was sufficient to atone for all sins forever. The repetition of sacrifices by the high priests highlighted the superiority of Jesus's once-for-all sacrifice. He offered himself without sin, putting an end to the need for further sacrifices. Through his complete and acceptable sacrifice, Jesus secured salvation for all who believe in him.

The high priests had to offer sacrifices daily, but Jesus, as the eternal High Priest, did not need to do so since His sacrifice was sufficient to atone for all sins forever. The repetition of sacrifices by the high priests highlights the superiority of Jesus's sacrifice, which was offered once for all. He offered Himself without sin and put an end to the need for further sacrifices. Through His complete and acceptable sacrifice, Jesus obtained complete salvation for all believers.
